2.2.Radius Problems for the class $\mathcal { F } _ { \mathcal { L P } }$ .Based on the definition of the class $\mathcal { F } _ { \mathcal { L P } }$ and pictorial representation of ${ \mathcal { L P } } ( \partial \mathbb { D } )$ (see Fig. $\bigstar$ we have $\mathrm { m a x } _ { | z | \leq 1 } \mathrm { R e } \left( \mathcal { L P } ( z ) \right) = \mathcal { L P } ( - 1 ) = 3 / 2$ This means $\mathrm { R e } z f ^ { \prime } ( z ) / f ( z ) < 3 / 2$ ,thus $f \in \mathcal { F } _ { \mathcal { L P } }$ may or may not be a univalent function. Therefore it is an interesting problem to establish the largest radius $r _ { 0 } < 1$ such that each $f \in \mathcal { F } _ { \mathcal { L P } }$ is starlike in $| z | \leq r _ { 0 }$ .In this section, we study some radius results for the class $\mathcal { F } _ { \mathcal { L P } }$ along with the classes $S ^ { * } ( \phi )$ and $\mathcal { F } ( \psi )$ for some special choices of $\phi ( z )$ and $\psi ( z )$ ，as mentioned in Table $\bigstar$ (see Appendix) and equation $( \overbrace { 1 . 1 } )$ ,respectively.
